TABREF219.text: Conclusion:Most mCRPC pts receiving enz concurrently with or subsequent to sip-T demonstrated signifi cant and sustained peripheral T cell and humoral immune responses through week 26. Th ese interim data suggest that both schedules were safe and that Introduction and Objective: Prostate cancer is the leading genitourinary malignancy in Ghana and is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in Ghana as in America. Th e objectives of the study are to determine the socio demographic features, the mode of presentation of the disease, the histo-pathological characteristics and to describe the treatment modalities employed for prostate cancer patients in Kumasi. and Methods: We prospectively obtained data on patients diagnosed of prostate cancer over a period of two years (Jan 2013 -Dec 2014) using structured questionnaire. Data was obtained on patient demographics, the clinical stage on presentation, histo-pathological characteristics and the treatment modality employed. Data was edited and transferred onto SPSS 16.0 for descriptive analysis. : Over the period, 120 cases were seen. Th e age range was from 43 to 83 years with a mean age of 68 years. Retired civil servants made up 42% of the patients. One hundred and fi ve (87%) of them had lower urinary tract symptoms at presentation. Common complications of the disease at presentation were bone/waist pains in 90 (75%); retention of urine in 58 (48.3%), hematuria in 42 (35%), anemia in 23 (19.2%), erectile dysfunction in another 23 (19.2%) and 20 (16.7%) had paraplegia. Majority (46%) had PSA levels ranging from 20-50ng/ml and 30% of them had PSA levels above 100ng/ml. Bone metastasis at presentation was 50%. All the patients had adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Th e Gleason scores ranged from 6-9 with Gleason 7 being the most predominant (45%), followed by Gleason score 9 (25%). Twenty (16.7%) of the patients had organ confi ned prostate cancer and thirty (25%) had locally advanced disease with 58.3% having metastatic disease.Conclusion:Most of our patients present late with unfavorable tumor characteristics. Public health education and screening programs will ensure early detection of prostate cancer and curative treatment for patients who require it.Management of Bone in Prostate CancerGuzman Martinez-Valls P, Doñate Iñiguez G, Maluff Torres A, Sanchez Rodriguez C, Honrubia Vilchez BDept. of Urology, "Los Arcos del Mar Menor" University Hospital, Pozo Aledo (San Javier), SpainIntroduction and Objective: Prostate Cancer (PC) represents a public health problem in the world. Th e bone is aff ected because the middle ages to the diagnosis is advanced, is the fundamental place of metastasis in the advanced stages and on the other hand treatment with androgenic deprivation (AD) increases resorption and reduces bone mineral density in those who use it. Problems with the skeleton have great impact on quality of life. Our goal is to present our management once has been most deeply known bone mineral exchange and the appearance of new molecules: recommendations and guidelines of treatment for the prevention of events bone. and Methods: We conducted the literature review using: "prostatic neoplasm, metastases, bone neoplasm, treatment, denosumab bone neoplasm". With the analysis of literature and evaluating diff erent consensuses have established the management of bone in patients with PC in our area.Results:We recommend drugs measures: avoid tobacco and alcohol, exercise, calcium and vitamin D supplements; According to past history of fractures (hip or vertebral body) or degree of loss of bone mineral measured by densitometry, treatment with Denosumab 60 mg c/6 months sc, vitamin D and calcium supplements. Patients with confi rmed metastases Denosumab sc sc c/4 weeks 120 mg or Zoledronic Acid 4 mg c/3-4 weeks along with supplements of vitamin D and calcium by identifying the patient: age, renal function, tolerance, mobility. : A "proper" handling of bone in PC since the beginning of the AD and treatment antiresorptive if it meets certain criteria improves the quality of life and reduces the risk of bone events. Th e prevention and management of bone involvement depends on each individual, their baseline and involvement: pain, compression, or risk, being in the patient multidisciplinary metastatic.Introduction and Objective: Epithelial to Mesenchymal transition (EMT) at the fi rst hormonal therapy is thought to play an essential role in obtaining castrate resistance for hormone naïve prostate cancer. So we studied EMT of prostatic cells aft er exposing various hormonal agents using transurethral resection (TUR) specimens.

TABREF220.text: Introduction and Objective:Th ere is now mounting evidence that the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR)

TABREF221.text: Results:We detected AhR proteins in prostate cancer cell lines and in human prostate cancer specimens. Th e induction of AhR signaling resulted in attenuation of the invasiveness of prostate cancer cells without aff ecting the cellular growth rate. Th ese results suggest that AhR signaling in prostate cancer cells facilitate invasion of these cells. : To date, few published studies have addressed the eff ect of AhR on cancer metastasis. In this study, our fi ndings indicate that the AhR signaling pathway may be a worthwhile target for therapeutic intervention in prostate cancer.Assessment of Arterial StiffnessUsing Cardio-Ankle Vascular Index in Patients with Prostate Cancer Treated by a Short-Term of Androgen Deprivation Therapy Oka R, Utumi T, Kamiya N, Lee F, Endo T, Yano M, Kamijima S, Nishimi D, Takanami M, Suzuki H

TABREF222.text: Results: Th e patients aft er 1 months, 3 months, and 6 months of ADT had signifi cantly higher Total cholesterol (p<0.001), higher LDL-cholesterol (p<0.001), higher HDL-cholesterol (p<0.001) in comparison with the before initiate ADT. CAVI value aft er 6 months of ADT increased in 28 patients (mean=0.46) and decreased in 25 patients (mean=0.63). It had not signifi cantly diff erence. Univariate analyses of predictors suggested that LDL-C/HDL-C ratio is predictive factor of increase of CAVI value. : Th e results of present study reveal that ADT of short period have an eff ect on dyslipidemia. But ADT of short period do not appear to be significant factors in risk of incident CVD. Th e eff ect of long period ADT needs to be examined in future studies.

TABREF223.text: Materials and Methods:Th e study was conducted on a group of 130 PCa patients diagnosed with between January 2012 and August 2013. PCa diagnosis was established based on the pathological exam of tissue fragments obtained by prostate biopsy or transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). Th e assessment protocol included preoperative patient history, International Prostate Symptoms Score (IPSS), digital rectal examination, abdominal and/or transrectal ultrasound (evaluating prostate volume and residual urinary volume), PSA and Qmax. Patients were divided into 4 groups: Group 1 -without associated infl ammatory lesions; Group 2 -mild infl ammation;Group 3 -moderate infl ammation; Group 4 -severe associated infl ammation. Prostate carcinoma was classifi ed according to the Gleason score. We compared the pathology fi ndings of patients diagnosed by prostate biopsy (77.70%) with those of patients undergoing TURP (22.30%).

TABREF224.text: Materials and Methods: mRNA expression microarray datasets for PCa and CRPC were extracted from Array-Express. mRNAs were stratifi ed according to malignant expression (T-Test p<0.001, FDR <0.05) in PCa versus Benign Prostate Hyperplasia (BPH), or in CRPC versus Androgen-Sensitive (AS) PCa, then sub-stratifi ed according to their reported susceptibility to undergo m6A-methylation. Methylated mRNAs were ranked according to their frequency of aberrant expression within multiple datasets and annotated functionally using gene enrichment soft ware. Th e percentages of aberrantly expressed mRNAs that were susceptible to m6A were: PCa, 37.6-54.6% and CRPC, 56.2-58.2%. Th e mean (SD) percentage of up-regulated (within top 10% percentile of highest fold-change) and down-regulated (within bottom 10% percentile of lowest fold-change) aberrantly expressed m6A-mRNAs was 4.4% (0.04) and 4.6% (0.04) in PCa, and 3.5% (0.05) and 2.0% (0.03) in CRPC. A total of 138 genes are shared in at least 5 of the 7 PCa datasets and, 127 genes are shared in both CRPC datasets. Following functional annotation, genes that are 35th CONGRESS OF THE SOCIÉTÉ INTERNATIONALE D'UROLOGIE -SIU 2015 ABSTRACT BOOK implicated in prostate oncogenesis include CAV1-2, EZH2, GSTP1, NCOA3, which are involved in angiogenesis, methylation of histones, DNA damage repair and transcription regulation respectively.:  We reported the distribution of aberrantly expressed m6A-mRNAs in PCa and CRPC, and identifi ed the genes that are implicated in PCa biology. In vitro studies evaluating this and identifying roles of these m6A-mRNAs in PCa/CRPC would allow further investigation into therapeutic agents.Introduction and Objective:Tumor hypoxia is a common feature of any cancer including prostate cancer and is associated with tumor progression. We had previously reported that chronic hypoxia accelerated cell migration and invasion. Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is one of the mechanisms by which cancer cells migrate and invade. We investigated whether the environment of chronic hypoxia induced EMT in prostate cancer cells. and Methods: Th e human prostate cancer cell line LNCaP was cultured under normoxia (21% O2), acute hypoxia (1% O2 for 48 hours), or chronic hypoxia (1% O2 for 6months). We investigated expressions of key EMT molecules at the level of mRNA and protein in the each LNCaP. : Th e expression of Slug (SNAI2) which is known as a transcriptional factor and a key molecule of EMT was specifi cally increased and Zonula Occuludens (ZO)-1 which is known as a tight junction protein, was decreased. But other EMT markers including E-cadherin as an epithelial marker, and Vimentin and N-cadherin as mesenchymal markers, were not signifi cantly changed. Knockdown of Slug inhibited cell migration and invasion in chronic hypoxia LN-CaP cells. But expression of ZO-1is not signifi cantly changed by knockdown of Slug. Th en we investigated what is the target for Slug and induces migratory and invasive behavior in prostate cancer cells. : Th ese results suggested that chronic hypoxia is not associated with EMT in prostate cancer cells. But Slug might be associated with prostate cancer progression. Another mechanism which induces cell migration and invasion via Slug is thought to exist. Now we investigate which gene is the target for Slug and induces migratory and invasive behavior in prostate cancer cells.Assessment of PCA3 and Multiparametric MRI's Collective Benefi ts when Deciding Initial Prostate Biopsy in Patients Whose PSA Level Is between 3-10 Ng/Ml Okcelik S 1 , Soydan H 2 , Ates F 2 , Berber U 3 , Saygin H 4 , Sonmez G 4 , Karademir K 2 Dept. of Urology, Beytepe Military Hospital, Ankara, Turkey; 2 Dept. of Urology, GATA Haydarpasa Teaching Hospital, Istanbul, Turkey; 3 Dept. of Pathology, Corlu Military Hospital, Tekirdag, Turkey;

TABREF225.text: Results: Between February 2013 and March 2014, 53 patients were included in our survey. One patient's urine was sent for PCA3 study without MRI. Contrast dynamic MRI of one patient wasn't able to be taken therefore other three MRI's were considered. Two patient's urine samples weren't examined for PCA3, because the urines were unable to be conveyed to the laboratory within 15 minutes so urine PCA3 RNA preservative could not be added. As one patient's urine sample didn't work in PCR it was excluded for PCA3 study. Th e mean age of patients were 61.22 ± 1.06. Mean PSA values were 5.13 ± 0.19 ng/ ml, respectively. Th e mean PCA3 score was 98.01 ± 23.13 and the mean prostate size was 48.96 ± 2.67 cc. Mean biopsy core number were 12.73 ± 0.13. Prostate cancer was detected in 19 of 53 patients. Mean tumor detected core was 3.21 ± 0.45. ASAP in two patients, Gleason grade 3 +3 PCa in thirteen patients, Gleason grade 3 + 4 PCa in four patients was observed. None of the patients had Gleason 4 +3 or above tumor grade. Overall tumor detection rate was 35.8%. Th e two patients whose fi rst biopsy was detected as ASAP, then diagnosed as benign aft er second biopsy. Two patients whose fi rst biopsy was ASAP are regarded as benign because no sign of tumor was detected in one-moth aft er second biopsy. Forty-nine patients had both the PCA3 score and multiparametric MRI. Th ere were 24 patients with high PCA3 score. Tumors were detected in 14 of these patients, accordingly, the PCA3's positive predictive value was detected as 58.33%, respectively. Twelve patients had both high PCA3 score and multiparametric MRI lesion. Th is tumor was detected in 11 of 12 patients. It is observed that, if both multiparametric MRI lesions are determined with high PCA3 scores, the positive predictive value elevated to 91.66%. Th ere were 25 patients who had normal PCA3 scores. Only one out of 25 patients had tumor and other 24 patients had no tumor. Accordingly, the negative predictive value of PCA3 was calculated as 96%. In none of these 25 out of 20 patients, MRI lesion weren't observed. Of these patients, in only 1 patient tumor was detected. Th e predictive value was evaluated as 95%, in patients with low PCA3 scores in case of no multiparametric MRI lesion wasn't detected. Sensitivity was 91.66% and specifi city 95% respectively. : If PCA3 level is high in patients with 3-10 ng/ml PSA value and having normal rectal examination results decision for biopsy could be supported by adding multiparametric MRI for directed biopsy to detect more tumors. Patients with low PCA3 value can be surveilled with no need to take MRI.

TABREF226.text: Effect on Hemostasis by an Absorbable Hemostatic Gelatin Sponge in Transrectal Prostate Needle BiopsyMita K, Kobatake K, Ohara S, Kato MHiroshima City Asa Hospital, Hiroshima, JapanIntroduction and Objective: To clarify the effi cacy on hemostasis by the gelatin sponge (SPONGOSTANTM Anal, Ethicon, Inc.) for rectal bleeding in transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy in a randomized controlled prospective study. and Methods: Th e subjects were 278 patients who underwent transrectal prostate needle biopsy. Th ey were randomly assigned to two groups by the envelope method; the gelatin sponge insertion group (Group A: 148 patients) and the non-insertion group (Group B: 130 patients). In Group A the gelatin sponge inserted into rectum immediately aft er biopsy.

TABREF227.text: Conclusion: Immediate insertion of the absorbable hemostatic gelatin sponge into the rectum aft er transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate needle biopsy signifi cantly decreases rectal bleeding without increasing patient symptoms, such as pain and a sense of discomfort.EPCA2.22: A Silver Lining for Early Diagnosis of Prostate CancerPourmand G, Safavi M, Noori M, Heydari F, Madshhadi R, Dehghani S, Alizadeh F, Salimi E, Hoodeh E, Pourmand N, Bladi LUrology Research Center, Tehran University of Medical Science, Tehran, IranIntroduction and Objective: PSA has been used as a marker for prostate cancer since 1980. However, PSA is tissue specifi c and not cancer specifi c. Recently, EPCA-2, a prostate matrix nuclear protein, has been proposed as a prostate specifi c cancer marker. Th is study was conducted to investigate whether EPCA-2 can be a more helpful marker in prostate cancer diagnosis. and Methods: One hundred seventy-six patients enrolled in this study had abnormal PSA or DRE and were candidated for a prostate needle biopsy. Th e consent form was completed. Five cc blood samples were obtained from each patient prior to biopsy and samples were frozen for EPCA-2 measurement. Cases were the cancer-diagnosed and others with BPH diagnosis were considered as controls. Univariate and multivariable analyses were done to assess the relationship between diff erent independent variables with cancer diagnosis. Th e diagnostic power of EPCA-2 for cancer was estimated at diff erent levels of PSA, according to the ROC curve. : One hundred seven patients were diagnosed with BPH (controls) and 69 with cancer (cases). Th e mean age of cancer cases was 70.33 (±9.02) while it was 63.34 (±9.47) for BPH cases (p<0.01). EPCA-2 and PSA were also signifi cantly diff erent (p<0.1). Th e multivariable logistic regression has shown that EPCA-2 has a signifi cant relationship with cancer diagnosis (OR=1.009, P=0.021). Aft er controlling other variables following stratifi cation for PSA, it was shown that EPCA-2 and cancer were correlated just when PSA was >10 (P<0.000). AUC was 0.694, for cancer prediction by EPCA-2 when PSA >10. : EPCA-2 has the power of diff erentiating BPH from cancer in prostate cancer suspects. Th is suggests that EPCA-2 can be helpful in diagnosing PCa and can be a preventive test to avoid unnecessary biopsies considering PSA and age of the patient.Comparison between Transperineal MRI-TRUS Fusion Target Prostate Biopsy versus Conventional Transrectal Systematic Prostate BiopsyKimura M 1 , Muto S 1 , Saito K 1 , Isotani S 1 , Ide H 1 , Yamaguchi R 1 , Horie S 2 Introduction and Objective: Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) guided biopsy has been used for the diagnosis of prostate cancer, but the technic is usually blind to cancer location. It has been criticized for both overdiagnosis of low grade tumors and underdiagnosis of clinically signifi cant prostate cancer. Multiparametric magnetic resonance (mMR) is enabling targeted biopsy of suspicious lesion. Th e detection of clinically signifi cant cancers has been facilitated by targeting according to PIRADS (Prostate imaging Reporting and Data System). In this study we compare in 55 patients, diagnostic accuracy of combination mMR cognitive targeted biopsy (MR-CB) using PIRADS and extended systematic template biopsy (TRUS-TB) versus extended systematic biopsy alone. and Methods: Included in this prospective study were 55 consecutive men with suspicious for prostate cancer. Median age was 66 years (range 49-84) and mean prostate specifi c antigen was 8.9 ng/ ml (range 1.81-44). Prebiopsy, all patients received 1.5 Tesla mMR of the prostate, consisting of T2-weighted, diff usion-weighted, and dynamic contrast-enhanced MR. Th e degree of suspicion from mMR fi ndings was classifi ed according to the PIRADS scoring system. A median of four targeted biopsies per lesion were obtained and 17-core extended systematic TRUS-TB was performed in every patients. Imaging data and biopsy results were analyzed. : Th e tumor detection rate was signifi cantly higher with MR-CB compared with TRUS-TB (27/55, 35th CONGRESS OF THE SOCIÉTÉ INTERNATIONALE D'UROLOGIE -SIU 2015 ABSTRACT BOOK 49%; 12/55, 21%, respectively, p<0.005). MR-CB detected prostate cancer in all signifi cant patients with positive TRUS-TB. Th e mean PIRADS score of all lesions was 2.6±0.52. Tumor lesions show a signifi cantly higher sum score compared with benign lesions (p<0.005). Regarding tumor malignancy, no high grade prostate cancer (Gleason score>7) was present at PIRADS score <3. : Combined MR-CB and TRUS-TB technic is more eff ective compared with TRUS-TB in detecting clinically signifi cant prostate cancer. PIRADS score give additional information and could be part of the decision-making process when considering biopsy. Th is method of prostate cancer detection may help to reduce the overdiagnosis and associated overtreatment of clinically insignifi cant prostate cancer by reducing unnecessary biopsy. Ekwueme K, Ismail N, Horsu S, Rashid A, Nwafor N, Bourns S, Venturi C, Das S, Awsare N, Pettersson BCountess of Chester Hospital, Chester, UKIntroduction and Objective: High false negative rates with TRUSB result in many patients requiring repeat biopsy for persistent suspicion of prostate cancer (PCa). We adopted a policy to off er MRI scan prior to TRUSB and subsequent biopsy to include targeted sampling of any abnormal area on the MRI. Herein, we evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of this strategy controlled with matched cohort who underwent conventional systematic TRUSB without MRI. and Methods: Between June 2012 and October 2013, 411 patients with raised PSA referred for TRUSB were retrospectively studied. Of these, 132 underwent pre-biopsy MRI (Group 1) and 279 underwent systematic TRUSB without MRI (Group 2). A hundred and ninety two cases were repeat TRUSB aft er a median of 1 (range 1-4) negative biopsies. Prior to TRUSB, Group 1 underwent 1.5 Tesla T2 and diff usion weighted imaging (dwi) MRI with Synergy body coil covering prostate and seminal vesicles. Areas suspicious of tumour were localised to one or more zones which were targeted at time of TRUSB. Statistical analysis was by Chi-square using IBM SPSS® version 20.Conclusions: MRI prior to conventional TRUSB does not improve cancer detection rate. As a negative MRI does not preclude PCa, we recommend that these patients should undergo MR targeted biopsy or transperineal saturation biopsy instead.Linares QuevedoA, Castellucci R, Sánchez Gómez, F, Cogollos Acuña I, Salinas Moreno S, Díez J, Salmerón Beliz I, Muñoz Fernández de Legaria M, Santonja C, Martínez-Piñeiro LInfanta Sofía Hospital, Madrid, SpainIntroduction and Objective: Th e ideal biopsy strategy to identify men with prostate cancer would be detection of only signifi cant prostate cancer and minimization of insignifi cant prostate cancer detection and consequent overtreatment. MRI targeted biopsy is a promising strategy that may off er these advantages compared to standard systematic TRUSGB. Th e aim of this study is to compare the diagnostic effi cacy of MRGB with TRUSGB. and Methods: A total of 168 biopsy-naive subjects with elevated PSA levels and/or an abnormal digital rectal examination (DRE) were consecutively enrolled from July 2011 through July 2014. All subjects underwent MRI prostate and TRUSGB. Subjects with normal MRI scans (Pi-rads 1, 2) underwent TRUSGB only, following the Vienna Nomogram; each equivocal (Pi-rads 3) or suspicious lesion (Pirads 4-5), was additionally biopsied using two cores. : Of 168 men, 69 (41.1%) had PCa. TRUSGB detected 60 cases of PCa (35.7 %) and 9 additionally cases of PCa were detected only by MRGB. Th e mp-MRI was equivocal for PCa (Pi-rads 3) in 46 subjects and suspicious (Pi-rads 4, 5) in 40 cases. Among these, TRUSGB detected PCa with Gleason score ≥7 in 75 % (Pi-rads 3) and 77.8 % (Pi-rads 4, 5) of the cases respectively. MRGB detected PCa with Gleason score ≥7 in 88.9 % (Pi-rads 3) and 90 % (Pi-rads 4, 5) of the cases respectively. Th e estimated NPV of MRGB for Pi-rads 3, and Pi-rads 4-5 lesions was 89% and 97.5 % respectively. : mpMRI followed by selective biopsy seems to improve the diagnosis of intermediate and high risk PCa compared to standard TRUSPB.Template-Guided Saturation Prostate Biopsy Effectively Detects Clinically Signifi cant Cancer That Is Diffi cult to Detect by Conventional Randomized BiopsyAndo T, Mori K, Nomura T, Sato F, Mimata HOita University, Yufu, JapanIntroduction and Objective: In many cases with suspected prostate cancer based on clinical fi ndings, the cancer is not detected by conventional randomized biopsy. When we repeat a biopsy in patients in whom cancer was not detected by conventional randomized biopsy, we perform a targeted prostate biopsy in combination with real-time virtual sonography (RVST-PBx), which allows real-time observation of fused images obtained with transrectal ultrasonography (TRUS) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), in patients with positive MRI fi ndings. Meanwhile, in patients without positive MRI fi ndings, we perform a template-guided saturation prostate biopsy (sPBx). Th e performance and signifi cance of these biopsy methods are reported herein. and Methods: Th is study included patients who underwent RVSTPBx or sPBx between August 2010 and February 2015 because their prostate-specifi c antigen (PSA) levels remained high or increased despite no evidence of cancer being detected by systematic prostate biopsy. Each biopsy was perineally performed in patients in the lithotomy position under lumbar anesthesia, and TRUS was combined with real-time tissue elastography (RTE), which visualizes the hardness of the prostate. As for RVSTPBx, 3-to 5-core MRI/TRUS-RTE fusion biopsies were performed in addition to conventional 12-core randomized biopsy. In sPBx, 1 core/ml of prostate tissue was collected by employing a template. Patient characteristics, cancer detection rates, cancer sites, and pathological fi ndings were evaluated according to each method. : RVSTPBx was performed in 14 patients with a mean age of 72 years, PSA level of 8.25 ng/ml, one previous biopsy and 16 biopsy cores. Meanwhile, sPBx was performed in 53 patients with a mean age of 69 years, PSA level of 12.7 ng/ml, 1.45 previous biopsies and 46.3 biopsy cores. Cancer was detected in 6 (42.9%) and 34 (64.2%) patients, respectively. In the patients undergoing RVSTPBx, 12 (24%) of the total 50 targeted biopsy cores were positive, while 13 (7.8%) of the total 167 cores of conventional randomized biopsy were positive. Out of 16 cores in total collected from the central zone by targeted biopsy, only one core was positive. Two patients (33%) met the criteria for active surveillance described in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines. In the patients undergoing sPBx, out of 118 cores in which cancer was detected, 82 cores (70%) were collected from the central zone. Two patients (5.9%) met the criteria for active surveillance described in the NCCN guidelines. No notable complications occurred in the patients undergoing either RVSTPBx or sPBx. : Both RVSTPBx and sPBx were shown to be eff ective test methods for increasing cancer detection rates. Our results suggest that more peripheral zone cores should be tested in patients with positive MRI fi ndings, and that more central zone cores should be tested in patients without positive MRI fi ndings. SPBx eff ectively detects clinically signifi cant cancer that is diffi cult to detect by conventional randomized biopsy.Introduction and Objective: Elastography is an imaging technique in which the diff erences in tissue stiff ness can be visualized. One of the problems for prostate cancer detection is false-positive results in patients with prostate hyperplasia. In this study, the tissue elastic modulus (Young's modulus) of the prostate gland was directly measured in prostatectomy specimens to compare with the results of elastography. Th is study was approved by the Ethics Committee of Hitachi General Hospital. and Methods: Patients scheduled to undergo radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer with a tumor diameter of ≥10 mm based on preoperative imagings were included. All patients provided written informed consent. Elastography was performed before each operation. Specimens were stored at 4ºC and delivered under refrigerated conditions. Sections were sliced at a 1-cm thickness before fi xation, with the lesion at the center. Each local area in the lesion or surrounding tissue was compressed using a stiff ness testing apparatus (Instron, Norwood, MA, USA) to measure the elastic modulus. Based on histopathological fi ndings, the compressed areas were classifi ed as normal gland in peripheral zone, normal gland in transitional zone, or cancerous tissue, and the tissue elastic modulus was calculated. Sections pathologically considered to have no cancer were excluded from the analysis.Results: Th e elastic modulus was measured in 14 patients. Th e mean tissue elastic modulus was 2.36 (range: 1.19-3.58) kPa for normal gland, 5.13 (range: 3.35-6.24) kPa for hyperplasia, 3.81 (range: 1.72-7.01) kPa for cancer ofG3+4, 5.17 (range: 4.78-5.52) kPa for cancer of G4+3, and 7.63 (range: 5.08-10.0) kPa for cancer of G3+5 and 4+5. Elastography could detect lesions of G8 or higher.

TABREF228.text: Evaluation of the Prostate Biopsy Indications: Chinese, Single Center Tian Y, Wang G, Ma L Peking University Th ird Hospital, Beijing, China Introduction and Objective: To describe the status of prostate biopsy in China and evaluate the prostate biopsy indications. and Methods: Reviewed of 717 cases of transrectal ultrasound-guided 12+1 pin transrectal prostate biopsy from January 2009 to December 2011. Excluded 30 cases of repeat biopsy, and included 591 cases, whose medical records could be checked, in the study. Prostate cancer 224 cases, non-prostate cancer 367 cases. Th e ages, PSAs and Gleason scores distribution of prostate cancer patients was analyzed. Calculated the PSAD and PSAV if possible. : Most prostate cancer patients got diagnosis over 60y, the diagnostic peak was 70 to 79 (54.5%), and most PSA was above 10ng/ml (66.1%). Th e Gleason scores was mainly below 7. TPSA (AUC=0.723, P<0.001) all had good effi cacy in diagnosis of prostate cancer. TPSA (r=0.433, P<0.001), PSAD (r=0.432, P<0.001) and PSAV (r=0.445, P=0.004) of prostate cancer patients was positively correlated with the Gleason scores. But f/T isn't correlated with the Gleason scores (P>0.05). In the PSA gray zone, f/T (AUC=0.691, P<0.001) and PSAD (AUC=0.704, P<0.001) had good effi cacy in diagnosis of prostate cancer, but TPSA and PSAV had no effi cacy in diagnosis of prostate cancer (P>0.05). TPSA, f/T, PSAD and PSAV all isn't correlated with the Gleason scores (P>0.05), but PSAD may tend to be correlated with the Gleason scores (r=0.330, P<0.10). : TPSA, f/T and PSAD all can be used for prostate cancer early diagnosis. PSAV and PSAD is correlated with the Gleason scores of the tumor, and may be help for the assessment of tumor progression.In the PSA gray zone, f/T and PSAD is all help for the diagnosis of prostate cancer. Considering the prediction of prostate cancer prognosis and cost-eff ectiveness, we prefer PSAD to f/T.Comparison of the Pre-Treatment Testosterone Levels in Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia and Prostate Cancer PatientsOrakwe D, Tijani K, Jeje E, Ogunjimi M, Ojewola RLagos University Teaching Hospital, Idi-Araba, Lagos, NigeriaIntroduction and Objective: Pre-treatment serum testosterone levels in men with prostate cancer has been studied and compared to serum levels in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) by various researchers with varying results and conclusions. Th e aim of this study was to compare serum testosterone and prostate specifi c antigen (PSA) levels of these same two groups of patients in a sub-Saharan African population. and Methods: One hundred and thirteen male patients (aged ≥40years) who presented with lower urinary tract symptoms and/or indications for prostate biopsy were recruited. Blood samples were collected and analyzed for serum testosterone and PSA. Prostate sizes were measured and PSA densities calculated before trans-rectal prostate biopsies were performed. : Fift y-four patients (47.8%) were diagnosed of prostate adenocarcinoma aft er prostate biopsy (and histology) while fi ft y-nine patients (52.2%) were grouped as patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Serum testosterone values were lower in the prostate cancer group (23.09±2.31nMol/L versus 24.37±1.94nMol/L in the BPH group) but this diff erence was statistically insignifi cant (p=0.671). Serum testosterone also did not diff er signifi cantly with Gleason grade and Gleason score in the subgroup of patients with prostate cancer. Serum PSA and PSA density (PSAD) values were signifi cantly higher in men with prostate cancer and in cancer patients with Gleason grade (≥4) and Gleason score (≥8). As an additional fi nding, when all patients were analyzed irrespective of diagnosis, the group of patients with serum PSA values ≥19ng/ml had signifi cantly lower serum testosterone levels when compared to those with serum PSA level <19ng/ml. Th is additional fi nd-ing could not be replicated within the diff erent groups of patients (BPH and prostate cancer) when they were split in the same manner into two groups. : Serum testosterone levels of patients with prostate cancer did not statistically diff er from those of patients with BPH. However, serum testosterone was found to be lower in those with high serum PSA values (above 19ng/ml) regardless of the fi nal diagnosis. Further research and studies with larger sample sizes are needed to explore this fi nding.Introduction and Objective:Multiparametric MRI (mpMRI) is an emerging technique aiming to improve upon the diagnostic sensitivity of prostate biopsy. Variance in interpretation and application of techniques means results may vary. Th ere is likely a learning curve to establish consistent reporting of mpMRI. Th is study aims to review current literature supporting the diagnostic utility of mpMRI when compared to radical prostatectomy (RP) and template transperineal biopsy (TTPB) specimens. Data suggests that compared to RP and TTPB specimens the sensitivity of mpMRI for prostate cancer (PCa) detection is 80-90% and the specifi city for suspicious lesions is between 50-90%. mpMRI has an increasing role for prostate cancer diagnosis, staging and directing management toward improving patient outcomes.and Methods: A systematic literature search, based on Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines of databases including Medline via OVID, Embase, CINAHL, Web of Science, ERIC via Pro-Quest was undertaken in March 2015. Keywords included: prostate, cancer, diagnosis, multiparametric, MRI, prostatectomy, transperineal in the form "((((((prostate) AND cancer) AND diagnosis) AND multiparametric) AND mri) AND prostatectomy) OR transperineal". Of the 1737 publications were initially identifi ed 47 were broadly relevant and 12 articles selected for detailed comparison. : Twelve relevant publications were identifi ed and compared. Th e sensitivity and specifi city of mp-MRI reported in the literature is approximately 80-90% and 50-90% when compared to RP and TTPB specimens. Numerous confounding variables were also reported including heterogeneity of MRI sequences, diff ering patient populations and radiologist experience. : mpMRI has an increasing role for prostate cancer diagnosis, staging and directing management toward improving patient outcomes. Th e sensitivity and specifi city of mpMRI reported in the 35th CONGRESS OF THE SOCIÉTÉ INTERNATIONALE D'UROLOGIE -SIU 2015 ABSTRACT BOOK literature is approximately 80-90% and 50-90% when compared to RP and TTPB specimens. Th is is less than what some expect, possibly refl ecting a learning curve for the technique of mpMRI. Does Specifi c Lower Urinary Tract Symptom Elevate the Risk of Prostate Cancer? Kim J, Sung H, Han D, Lee S Introduction and Objective: Despite the general fears linking Lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS) with prostate cancer, the association between LUTS and prostate cancer detection rate is not much discovered yet. We investigated whether each specifi c symptoms of LUTS are related to the elevated odds of prostate cancer detection by evaluating the correlation of the each subscales of International Prostate Symptom Score (IPSS) refl ecting the severity of specifi c LUTS with the cancer detection of a multi (≥10)-core transrectal prostate biopsy. and Methods: From July 2007 to Jan 2013, 3,267 patients underwent transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) prostate biopsies due to elevated PSA levels ranging between 2.5 and 30 ng/ml or abnormal digital rectal exams (DREs). Univariate and multivariate logistic analysis was used to assess the association of each symptoms of LUTS and prostate cancer detection. Th e predictive accuracy of the multivariate model was assessed based on the receiver operating characteristics-derived area under the curve.

TABREF229.text: Use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging in Prostate Cancer Facilitates Better Candidate Selection for Active Surveillance Sivaraman A, Sanchez-Salas R, Ahallal Y, Barret E, Rozet F, Galiano M, Prapotnich D, Cathala N, Mombet A, Cathelineau X Institute Mutualiste Montsouris, Paris, France Introduction and Objective:To evaluate the changing trends in appropriate candidate selection for Active Surveillance (AS) aft er routine use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) for Prostate Cancer (PCa), using Transperineal Template guided Mapping Biopsy (TTMB). and Methods: We retrospectively analyzed 462 TTMB performed at our institution(2008 -2014)   and identifi ed 165 patients with low risk cancer eligible for AS based on TransRectal UltraSound (TRUS) biopsy (Prostate Specifi c Antigen (PSA) < 10 ng/ml, Gleason score (GS) ≤ 6, clinical stage ≤ T2a, unilateral disease and maximum of 1/3 positive cores and < 50% of total length) underwent TTMB. Routine use of MRI for PCa was started since 2012, hence the study population was divided into two groups G1(Before  MRI, 2008 -2011) and G2 (Aft er MRI, 2012 -2014. We compared the TTMB results between two groups for the rates of GS upgrading (GS ≥ 7) and upstaging (bilateral) as compared to initial and detection of clinically signifi cant caner (maximum cancer core length (MCCL) ≥ 4 mm and/or Gleason grade ≥ 3 + 4). : Th e clinical and biopsy characteristics of G1 and G2 are shown inTable 1. MRI was performed in 82.1% patients in G2. TTMB detected cancer in G1 -64 (65%) and G2 -52 (77.6%) patients. Th e rates of upgrade and detection of clinically signifi cant cancer was signifi cantly in lower in G2 aft er routine use of MRI. : Routine use of MRI in PCa appears to aid in better candidate selection for active surveillance.Transperineal Template Guided Prostate Biopsy: An Analysis of Our OutcomesAhmed M, Th akare N, Chinegwundoh FBarts Health NHS Trust, London, UKIntroduction and Objective: In the United Kingdom prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men. Transperineal template prostate biopsy (TMP) is gaining popularity as a diagnostic modality for prostate cancer. We aim to present our data for TMP performed on patients with elevated PSA and previous negative TRUS guided biopsy. and Methods: Prospective analysis of retrospectively collected data on patients undergoing TMP at Bart's and the London NHS Trust between 2009 and 2014. A total of 327 cases were analysed aft er exclusion of cases with unavailable histology. : Mean age of patients at TMP was 65 years (45 -83) with 5.2% undergoing their fi rst biopsy (17/327) and at least 11.9% for restaging (39/327). Mean corrected PSA was 13.9 (0.05 -132) and average of 38 cores taken per biopsy. Our TMP histology demonstrates a signifi cant cancer detection rate of 37% (121/327) with majority of the previous negative TRUS biopsies attributing to larger prostates. Fift y-seven percent of cancers were detected in the anterior zone (AZ) but only 9% were limited only to AZ. Th e probability of detecting signifi cant prostate cancer in larger prostates with multiple previous neg-UP.261,Table 1. Clinical and TRUS Biopsy Characteristics UP.261,Table 2. TTMB Outcomes ative TRUS biopsies (≥4) is rather low but we cannot comment on its clinical signifi cance. and Objective: As the number of patients with low-volume, low-grade localised prostate cancer (PCa) increased, less invasive focal therapies have been introduced based on the accumulated pathological and clinical fi ndings aft er radical prostatectomy. We previously reported that radical transurethral resection of prostate cancer (TUR-PCa) could be a radical therapy against localised PCa. We examined our data to evaluate whether focal TUR-PCa could be a viable focal therapy. and Methods: We analysed the distribution of cancer foci in 209 patients treated with radical TUR-PCa. And clinical results of 79 patients with unilateral PCa were studied because such patients seemed to be the most suitable candidates of focal TUR-PCa.In additional 16 patients we made a preliminary study of focal TUR-PCa. We radically resected the aff ected one lobe with the unaff ected lobe being resected less vigorously, or we radically resected both lobes except for the prostate tissues near the neurovascular bundle. : Pathological study revealed there were cancer foci near the neurovascular bundle bilaterally in 35%, unilaterally in 39% and no cancer bilaterally in 26%, suggesting the possibility of focal TUR-PCa.Patients' age ranged from 58 to 91 years and preoperative PSA, 0.70 to 17.30 ng/mL. At the fi nal follow-up, there were 75 (94.9%) patients with stable PSA levels: PSA≤0.01, 40 cases; ≤0.02, 12; ≤0.03, 5; ≤0.04, 5; ≤0.1, 5; ≤1.0, 8. PSA failure developed in 4 (5.1%). Th e actuarial biological non-recurrence rate was 98.2% for the pathological stage pT2a-b at 88 months and 90.5% for pT2c at 84 months. Concerning the 16 patients treated by focal TUR-PCa, the follow-up period ranged from 3 to 53 months (median, 22.0). Postoperative PSA was stable between 0.007 and 0.406 ng/mL. No patients suff ered from urinary incontinence. Bladder neck contracture developed in only 1 patient and favorable results were obtained concerning the erectile function. : Focal TUR-PCa was considered to be a promising option among focal therapies against localized PCa because of possible advantages of both cancer control and quality of life. A longer follow-up results will be presented. and Objective:We investigated about the change of the renal function for prostate cancer patients who discontinued ADT. and Methods: Between 2009 and 2014, among 121 patients that performed prostate biopsy in our institute and were diagnosed prostate cancer pathologically and received ADT over 6 months, 60 patients who underwent the radiotherapy on stage B and C were statistically examined retrospectively. Th e renal function was assessed using estimated glomerular fi ltration rate (eGFR.) Th e ΔeGFR was calculated by (posttreatment eGFR-pretreatment eGFR)/pretreatment eGFR ×100). Th e discontinuing group was defi ned only for 6 months with ADT and the continuing group was defi ned for 12 months with ADT. We analyzed statistically about age, the ΔeGFR at baseline, 1, 3, 6 and 12 months, PSA, testosterone, hemoglobin, stage, Gleason score, comorbidity, body mass index, heart rate, cardio-thoracic ratio. : A total of 60 patients (discontinuing group: n= 23, continuing group: n=37) were analyzed. All patients underwent the radiotherapy aft er ADT for 6 months. Th e median hemoglobin was 14g/dl (range10.8-17.1g/ dl) in discontinuing group and 14.8 g/dl (range 12.6-16.8g/dl) in continuing group, respectively (P=0.0415). Th e median ΔeGFR at baseline, 1, 3, 6 and 12 monthsEvidence-based Best Practice Elements Pre-op Digital rectal examination performed for clinical staging Pre-operative PSA available within 6 months from surgery Biopsy-proven histopathological diagnosis is available Estimate nodal involvement and extraprostatic extension using pre-operative nomogram e.g. MSKCC nomogram Estimate risk of recurrence after defi nitive treatment using pre-operative variables e.g. D'Amico classifi cation Pelvic CT or MRI to exclude nodal disease if cT3 or PSA>20 or Gleason score >6 Bone scan to exclude bone metastases if symptomatic bone pain or PSA >20 or Gleason score 8 or more Assess preoperative erectile function, e.g. IIEF Perioperative management of antiplatelets and anticoagulation Intra-op Type and screen must be available before the start of surgery Intravenous prophylactic antibiotics to be given in accordance with hospital guidelines Redosing of prophylactic antibiotics if surgery is more than 4 hours Pelvic lymphadenectomy to be performed for D'Amico high-risk cases Post-op Chest physiotherapy when back in ward after operation Ambulate on 1st post-operative day for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis Follow-up Pelvic fl oor training to improve continence UP.268, Table 1.

TABREF230.text: Methods: A retrospective analysis of patients between January 2009 and December 2014 was conducted in a district general hospital in North Wales. Of 1083 newly diagnosed patients, 8 were found to be in the age group of 40-49. Mean age at presentation was 46 years (range 43-49), with 2 having family history. : Mean PSA at presentation-7.1ng/ml (range 2.3-22) for 7 out of 8 patients with one outlier. Four patients had abnormal prostate on DRE, T2 in 2 patients and T3 in 2 patients. All patients underwent TRUS + biopsy, 5 patients had bilateral disease; 3 had unilateral disease. Th e mean Gleason scores was 7 (range 6-9). Two had LHRH agonist and radiotherapy, 6 patients underwent radical prostatectomy and 1 had positive margins (seminal vesicle invasion on pre-operative MRI, with PSA 1.7 at 6 weeks postoperatively) was given salvage radiotherapy. : CAP in the young patients is no more aggressive than presenting at later age according to the radiological staging and histological diagnosis. Genetic counselling for younger group with fi rst degree relative with history of CAP is at present matter of debate.National Cancer Center Hospital East, Chiba, JapanIntroduction and Objective: Degarelix has been reported to off er superior control of lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) compared to luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LHRH) agonist. However, whether degarelix can reduce acute genitourinary toxicity associated with irradiation when used as neoadjuvant androgen-deprivation therapy (ADT) remains unclear. Th e aim of this study was to evaluate the effi cacy of degarelix as neoadjuvant ADT followed by radiation therapy in the control of acute genitourinary toxicity compared to LHRH agonist. and Methods: Between May 2005 and May 2014, a total of 355 patients who had received neoadjuvant ADT for intermediate-to high-risk prostate cancer followed by intensity-modulated radiation therapy (IMRT) were enrolled in this study. Of these, 25 patients were treated with degarelix and 330 with LHRH agonist. Both groups received neoadjuvant ADT in combination with antiandrogen agents for 6 months prior to IMRT. Propensity-score matching was performed using clinical variables, including age, prostate-specifi c antigen level, clinical stage, biopsy Gleason score, D' Amico risk stratifi cation, prostate volumes, history of diabetes mellitus, pre-treatment use of alpha-1 blockers, radiation dose per fraction (2 or 3 Gy/fraction) and pre-treatment frequency of nocturnal urination. Genitourinary toxicity was estimated according to the National Cancer Institute Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) version 3.0 guidelines and acute toxicity was defi ned as any toxicity developing within 3 months aft er the end of radiation therapy. : Propensity-score matching resulted in 23 patients in each group. Th e matched cohort showed no signifi cant diff erences in clinical variables between groups. In the matched cohort, acute genitourinary toxicity was detected at a signifi cantly lower rate in the degarelix group than in the LHRH agonist group (39.1% vs. 69.6%, p=0.038). Post-treatment frequency of nocturnal urination was also signifi cantly lower in the degarelix group than in the LHRH agonist group (2.21±0.27 vs. 3.34±0.27, p=0.005). : Th e results of our study suggests that degarelix might reduce acute genitourinary toxicity UP.270,Table 1.UP.270,Figure 1.35th CONGRESS OF THE SOCIÉTÉ INTERNATIONALE D'UROLOGIE -SIU 2015 ABSTRACT BOOK associated with IMRT compared to LHRH agonist, and might be useful as neoadjuvant ADT followed by irradiation.

TABREF231.text: Materials and Methods:Th irty low-intermediate risk prostate cancer patients (pts) were enrolled: cT1c-T2a, N0, M0; PSA≤10ng/ml; GS≤3+3 (3+4 in Canada only). Under general anesthesia, the ultrasound device (TULSA-PRO, Profound Medical Inc.) is positioned in the prostatic urethra with MRI guidance. Treatment planning is performed under MRI visualization with therapeutic intent of conservative whole-gland ablation, including 3 mm safety margins at periphery and apex. Ultrasound treatment is deliv-ered under closed-loop continuous MRI thermometry feedback control. Patients recover as outpatients. Primary endpoints are safety and feasibility, with follow-up to 12 months. Clinical monitoring is 5 years, including serial PSA, TRUS biopsies, IPSS and IIEF. 12 months (n=17). MRI and biopsy fi ndings at 12 months show diminutive prostate volumes, with average 45% fi brosis. Biopsies are positive in 55% of patients, though with average 62% reduction in total biopsy core cancer length.UP.275, Figure 1. Boxplots Showing EPIC Scores at Baseline, One Week and Four Weeks Post-IRE Treatment: No Signifi cant Difference Was Found between Baseline and Four Weeks Post-IREInstitute Mutualiste Montsouris, Paris, FranceIntroduction and Objective: To compare the perioperative and oncologic outcomes of Focal Cryotherapy (FC) in unilateral, organ confi ned prostate cancer (PCa) with Gleason score (GS) 6 vs. GS 7 (3+4). and Methods: We analyzed 108 patients who underwent primary FC -hemiablation at our institution(March 2009 -February 2014. Cancer localization was done with transrectal ultrasound (TRUS) guided prostate biopsy and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). Under general anesthesia, FC was delivered through transperineal needles placed in the aff ected lobe with TRUS guidance. Follow-up constitutes of Prostate Specifi c Antigen (PSA) every 3 months and MRI and control biopsy at 12 months.

TABREF233.text: Materials and Methods:Plasma samples were obtained from 58 patients with PC: 36 with CRPC and 22 with non-CRPC. We determined plasma levels of HGF, activated-MSP and HGFA immunohistochemically using Enzyme-Linked Immuno Sorbent Assay (ELISA) kit, and analyzed their relationships with clinicopathological characteristics such as Gleason grade and bone metastasis in CRPC.Results: Plasma levels of HGF, MSP and HGFA in patients with CRPC were predominantly higher than in those with non-CRPC (HGF: P<0.0004; MSP: P<0.018; HGFA: P<0.001), and HGF and MSP levels were signifi cantly correlated (P=0.003). In the CRPC group, correlations between plasma level of HGF and MSP and Gleason score were not observed statistically; however, high plasma MSP level was signifi cantly correlate with bone metastasis. (P=0.036). : HGF, MSP and HGFA expression are positively associated with PC progression. And furthermore, plasma MSP level is signifi cantly associated with bone metastasis in CRPC patients. Our results indicate important role of HGF/MET and MSP/RON signaling system in CRPC with (or without) bone metastasis. However, further examination will be needed to clarify the mechanism.Introduction and Objective: Th ere has been no consensus on the blood adrenal androgen concentrations in men with diff erent stages and pathological grades of prostate cancer. In this study, dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) concentrations in blood were examined by newly developed ultra-sensitive LC-MS/MS method. and Methods: We analyzed 196 men (mean age 70 years) diagnosed as prostate cancer from November 2005 to July 2007. Th ose patients received systematic needle biopsy, and peripheral blood sampling was conducted for the purpose of simultaneous determination of DHEA. DHEA concentrations in blood were determined by LC-MS/MS method. DHEA levels in blood were compared with Gleason score and clinical stage by multivariate analyses. : Median value of PSA and prostate volume measured by ultrasound were 11.5 ng/mL and 27.7 cc, respectively. Median values of DHEA in blood were 1506.4 pg/mL. Th ere was no correlation between serum DHEA and clinical variables such as age, serum PSA, and prostate volume measured by ultrasound. In multivariate analysis, serum PSA and serum DHEA levels were signifi cantly associated with poor prognosis factors in men with prostate cancer. Low serum DHEA levels in men with prostate cancer were signifi cantly related to high Gleason score (p=0.020) and advanced clinical stage (p=0.043).

TABREF234.text: PSA Anxiety: PSA Syndrome before and after Diagnosis of Prostate Cancer Takeda H, Nakano Y, Narita H Tosei General Hospital, Seto, Japan Introduction and Objective: Th e entire journey associated with early detection is anxiety laden. An elevated prostate-specifi c antigen (PSA), whether cancer related or not, is anxiety provoking, a condition described as PSA syndrome. Th e discomfort and risks of biopsy add to this situation. Th e cancer diagnosis comes with a lot of emotional change. Th is study is Introduction and Objective: Prostate specifi c antigen (PSA) and its free (f-PSA) and total (t-PSA) isoforms are commonly used in clinical practice. Clinical data have demonstrated that Pro-PSA and associated prostate health index (PHI) could increase specifi city and sensitivity of PSA assessment in prostate cancer (PC) patients. Th e aim of the study was to assess effi cacy of combined PSA assessment with 3 isoforms in correlation with clinical and morphological characteristics of the disease.and Methods: Serum concentrations of f-PSA, t-PSA and Pro-PSA were assessed with chemiluminescence method (Beckman Coulter Access 2) in 223 PC patients, undergone surgical treatment. Morphological stage pТ2a-T2b was verifi ed in 12 patients, pТ2c -in 138, pТ3a -in 38 and pТ3b -у 35. Postop-Results: Mean serum concentrations of t-PSA (12.5±0.9 vs. 10.3±0.6, p=0.039), f-PSA (9.0±0.6 vs. 10.5±0.4, p=0.029) and PHI (79.2±4.6 vs. 64.8±2.9, p=0.009) signifi cantly diff ered in subgroups of PC patients with Gleason grade 7 (3+4) and 5-6, respectively. Moreover, signifi cant diff erence was observed in serum concentrations of Pro-PSA (33.0±4.0 vs. 21.3±1.5, p=0.008), %Pro-PSA (3.2±0.3 vs. 2.4± 0.1, p=0.013) and PHI (114.6±12.1 vs. 79.2±4.6, p=0.008) in subgroups of PC patients with Gleason score 7 (4+3) and 7 (3+4), respectively. In subgroups with pТ2a-b and pТ2c diff erence in concentrations of PSA isoforms was not signifi cant. In subgroups with pТ3a и pТ2c disease diff erence in concentration of t-PSA (14.6±1.4 vs. 9.8±0.5, p=0.002), %f-PSA (8.3±0.6 vs. 10.7±0.4, p=0.001), Pro-PSA (25.8±2.6 vs. 18.7±1.0, 8±7.1 vs. 63.07±2.4, p=0.0002) was statistically signifi cant. In subgroups with pТ3b and pТ3a disease signifi cant diff erences were observed only for concentrations of Pro-PSA (35.5±3.6 vs. 25.8±2.6, p=0.032), %Pro-PSA (3.2±0.2 vs. 2.6± 0.1, p=0.019) and PHI (119.1±10.0 vs. 91.8±7.1, p=0.030). : Complex assessment with 5 PSA isoforms (t-PSA, f-PSA, Pro-PSA, %Pro-PSA and PHI) could increase accuracy of preoperative PC staging. Introduction and Objective: Th e development of a molecular diagnostic assay involves a series of feasibility and analytic studies; clinical adoption requires a suitable level of clinical evidence (Simon JNCI 2009).

TABREF235.text: of Pre-Treatment PSA, Gleason Score and MRI Staging in Newly Diagnosed Prostate Cancers Bhuvanagiri A 1 , Kannan S 1 , Szeto Y 1 , Abdul Z 1 , Alexandrou K 1 , Ahiaku E 1 , Williams W 1 , Breeze J 2 35th CONGRESS OF THE SOCIÉTÉ INTERNATIONALE D'UROLOGIE -SIU 2015 ABSTRACT BOOK Introduction and Objective:We conducted a study to look at the association of pre-treatment PSA, Transrectal (TRUS) biopsy Gleason Score (GS) and staging MRI (MR) in newly diagnosed prostate cancer patients. and Methods: A retrospective analysis of patients between January 2009 and December 2014 was conducted in a district general hospital in North Wales. Th e mean age was 69 years (range 43 to 86). A total of 1083 patients had newly diagnosed prostate cancer, with 724 patients having complete data i.e. PSA, TRUS biopsy and MR. Staging for this analysis was determined by the MR report. : Multivariate analysis showed a signifi cant effect in T (p<0.05), N (p<0.05) and M (p<0.001) staging in relation to PSA and GS. Th ere was also significant interaction between T and M staging (p<0.05). In Univariate analysis, GS and PSA showed an increase with T staging up to T2C stage (p<0.05), whereas N staging showed a non-signifi cant eff ect on GS while giving a signifi cant eff ect on PSA (p<0.05). M staging was only signifi cant for GS (p<0.001) but not PSA. : Our study confi rms positive association of organ-confi ned prostate cancer on MR (T2C) with PSA and biopsy GS, lymph node status with PSA, and bone metastasis with GS. It does also show that conventional MR staging is essential for patients with high risk disease. cancer patients who developed radiation induced side-eff ects. and Methods: Between April 2006 and March 2014, 6 prostate cancer patients treated with EBRT (dosage 69.3 -72 Gy) developed RTOG/EO-RTC grade 3 radiation induced side-eff ects at Nippon Medical School. Patients received 100% oxygen in a hyperbaric chamber at a pressure of 2.5 atmospheres absolute, 20 minutes pressurization, 60 minutes treatment, 20 minutes decompression once a day, 6 times a week. 20 HBO treatments were performed per course. Aft er every course of HBO treatment, therapeutic effect was evaluated using RTOG/EORTC Late Radiation Morbidity Scoring Schema. : Th e average age was 78.8 years old. Five hemorrhagic proctitis, and 2 hemorrhagic cystitis.

TABREF236.text: Results: Th e cohort of men undergoing RARP had a median age of 64 (range 42-77) with predominately Gleason 7 disease (78%) and a positive margin rate of 18%. Seventy-two percent of men (85 patients) were graded as having strong PFM strength pre-operatively, 14% (17 patients) were graded as moderate and 11% weak (13 patients). Th ree men were noted to have inappropriate PFM use. Weak PFM strength at 4 weeks correlated with incontinence as expected. Th ere was no signifi cant relationship between Gleason score, T-stage or pre-op PFM strength and post-op PFM strength. Younger men with weak PFM strength at 1 week were more likely to have improved strength at 4 weeks. : PFM strength is an important factor in urinary incontinence post-RARP. Our data demonstrated no signifi cant pre-operative predictors of weak PFM strength post-operatively. Studies of larger cohorts of men with longer follow-up could shed more light on risk factors for pelvic fl oor weakness post-op.Introduction and Objective: T1c prostate cancer cases have clinically inapparent tumor on digital rectal examination. However, prostate cancer is subsequently detected on needle biopsy. Generally biopsies are performed due to a suspicious prostate-specifi c antigen (PSA). PSA is a known clinical predictor of extracapsular disease. We aim to assess the relationship between PSA and pathological T stage in cases of T1c prostate cancer. and Methods: A retrospective analysis of the Victorian Prostate Cancer Registry data was conducted. A total of 1,544 cases of T1c prostate cancer with recorded PSA at diagnosis were identifi ed. Date of diagnosis ranged from 2009-2013. We used logistic regression to calculate odds ratios (OR) to assess the relationship between PSA and pathological T stage. : Overall 30% of T1c cases have extracapsular (T3/T4) pathology; 19.5% of T1c cases with PSA 0-5ng/dL have extracapsular disease. Th ereaft er the OR for extra capsular disease increases with PSA level. Compared to a PSA of 0-5, PSA 5-10 had an OR of 1.9, PSA 10-15 had an OR of 2.7, PSA 15-20 had an OR 5.5 and PSA >20 had an OR of 6.2 for extra capsular disease. (Table 1). : Using a Victorian population, we have demonstrated that the odds of extracapsular disease increases with PSA in cases of T1c prostate cancer. Our results are similar to existing international data. Partin tables covering a similar period (2006-2013) found that 46% of patients with T1c disease and PSA >10 had extracapsular disease. We also found 46% of our patients with T1c disease and PSA >10 had extracapsular disease. Th is study highlights the importance of PSA in determining the signifi cance of T1c disease. Introduction and Objective: A digital rectal examination forms (DRE) part of the core assessment for prostate cancer both for screening and staging purposes. An abnormal DRE increases the likelihood of prostate malignancy, especially in the context of an elevated prostate-specifi c-antigen (PSA). However, its utility is limited. It misses a signifi cant proportion of cancers, whilst detecting mainly higher stage cancers. One study involving 565 DREs, concludes only a 52% concordance for T2 suspected clinical disease. We aim to measure the ability of the clinical T stage to correctly identify pathological stage. and Methods: A retrospective analysis of Victorian Prostate Cancer Registry data was conducted comparing recorded clinical and pathological UP.301, Table 1. Shows Final Pathological T Stage of Clinical T1c Cancers and Their Associated PSA UP.302, Table 1. Shows Participant Clinical T Stage and Final Pathological T Stage following Radical Prostatectomy T stages. Th is includes men diagnosed with prostate cancer from 2009-2013.

TABREF241.text: Review of Urological Complications following Paediatric Renal Transplantation Smit S, McCulloch M, Gajjar P, Nourse P, Muller E, Lazarus J, Pontin A, Miller A, Numanoglu A, Kahn D University of Cape Town, Cape Town, South Africa Introduction and Objective: To review the urological complications following paediatric renal transplantation performed at Red Cross Children's War Memorial Children's Hospital, Cape Town, South Africa. and Methods: Retrospective folder review of all transplants performed from 1996 to 2014. Urological complications were classifi ed as: vesico-ureteric refl ux, urine leak, ureteric stenosis, or unexplained hydronephrosis.

TABREF242.text: 1850 Laparscopic Donor Nephrectomy Done by a Single Team: A Cost Effective Model for the Developing Country Kumar A, Gula A, Dassi V, Chauhan U, Sharma A, Yadav R Max Superspeciality Hospital, New Delhi, India Introduction and Objective: To review the results, complications and cost eff ectiveness of 1850 cases of laparoscopic donor nephrectomy done by a single team. and Methods: From 2000 to 2014, 1850 laparoscopic donor nephrectomies were done. Donors were followed up to a month and reviewed at one year. First 46 cases were laparoscopic assisted, three were hand assisted and rest was pure laparoscopic. Th ere were 110 right donors and 1740 were left side. On left side, 1696 cases had transperitoneal nephrectomy and only 44 had retroperitoneal approach. On right side, Initial 22 cases had lap or hand assisted, 42 patients had retroperitoneal and 46 cases had transperitoneal approach. Weck Hemolock clips was used in 1770 cases for both arterial and venous control. Vascular stapler was used in rest of the cases. In initial 22 patients of right side, lap or open satinskey clamp was used for renal vein, TA 30 stapler was used in 62 and hemolock clips controlled rest. Among all, 1590 kidney was retrieved by pfanansteil incision and in 184 by 5 cm iliac fossa incision, 22 by 6 cm subcostal incision and 54 obese donors have small fl ank incision.

TABREF244.text: Materials and Methods: Data were collected from 32 French transplantation centers. Cases of renal graft de novo tumors treated as RCC between January 1988 and October 2014 were included. A total of 115 allograft kidney de novo tumors were diagnosed. TABREF247.text: Methods: A retrospective review was completed for all patients who underwent in-offi ce testing with intracavernous pharmacologic erection augmented by visual sexual stimulation and CDDU from 2008 to 2014 by one Urologist. A comparison of PD patients without ED to PD patients with ED was accomplished using Fisher's exact test, Wilcoxon rank sum test or the Kruskal-Wallis methods. : A total of 451 patients were found to have PD, with a median age of 63 (26-95) and a mean BMI of 27.1 (18.1-46.1). Seventy four percent of patients had a moderate degree of curvature, defi ned as 15-60°, whereas only 15% had a severe degree of curvature. Ninety three percent of men were sexually active with only 22% achieving a score greater than 21. PD plus ED patients were signifi cantly older than PD patients alone (64 vs. 62, p<0.001). Dupuytren's contracture was present in equal frequency between both groups. CDDU analysis was utilized to determine the presence (64.3%) and etiology of ED with the following results: arterial insuffi ciency (47/451, 10.4%), cavernous venous occlusive disease (CVOD) (134/451, 29.5%), mixed vascular disease (111/451, 24.4%), and normal arterial/venous fl ow (162/451, 35.7%). : Th is analysis defi nes baseline CDDU characteristics in PD patients. At least 6 out of 10 PD patients present with vascular irregularities as demonstrated by Doppler analysis. Plaque size did not correlate with the presence of ED (p=0.9). Our results indicate that the etiology of ED in patients with PD is variable, although a majority (54%) has a component of CVOD.Incidence of Peyronie's Disease in a Men's Health Clinic and Its Comorbid AssociationsHabous M 1 , Abdelwahab O 2 , Binsaleh S 3 , Mahmoud S 4 , Malkawi I 5 , Santucci R 5

Th e analysis included need for either urologic or radiologic interventions, need for step-down or ICU care, duration of stay, and length of hospital admission prior to transfer.

TABREF252.text: Practicality of Using Score Systems to Predict the Outcome of Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy Lim B, Yam W, Lim S, Goh D, Ng F Changi General Hospital, Singapore Introduction and Objective: We aim to investigate the use of scoring systems to correlate with outcomes and complications aft er percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL). and Methods: We retrospectively examined the records of 194 patients who underwent PCNL in between July 2008 and December 2014 in our institution. Guy's and S.T.O.N.E. scoring systems were calculated. Preoperative characteristics and outcomes were analysed. Stone free status is defi ned as residual fragments of ≤4mm. : Th e stone free patients and those with residual fragments have similar distribution in age, sex, stone laterality, American Society of Anaesthesiologists score and BMI. Overall stone free rate is 59.8%. Stone-free patients had signifi cantly lower Guy's score (2.9 vs. 3.4, p=0.000) and S.T.O.N.E score (7.8 vs. 8.7 p=0.029). Logistic regression analysis showed that both Guy's and S.T.O.N.E systems were signifi cantly associated with stone free status; OR 1.9 (p<0.000) and OR 2.4 (p=0.002) respectively. Th ere is also a positive correlation in both Guy's and S.T.O.NE scoring systems in terms of duration of operation; r=0.2, p=0.030 and r=0.2, p=0.002 respectively. Th ere was no signifi cant diff erence in the areas under the curves for the Guy's and S.T.O.N.E. scoring systems (0.622 [95% CI 0.54-0.70] vs. 0.66 [95% CI 0.58-0.75]; p=0.48). Th ere is also no signifi cant association between both scoring systems in terms of complications (p=0.360 and p=0.370) and length of hospitalisation (p=0.516 and p=0.885). : Guy's and S.T.O.N.E scores can accurately predict stone free status. Th e scores should however be interpreted with caution as they do not predict complications accurately. TABREF253.text: Materials and Methods: Aft er informed consent andEthical committee clearance 134 patients underwent ESWL procedure in Department of Urology in our hospital from January 2014 to December 2014. Inclusion criteria were adult patients with solitary renal calculus less than two centimetre in size. Stone analysis was done aft er collecting strained urine samples for fragments three days aft er procedure. All the patients underwent ESWL under supervision of a single Physician and Technician on Siemens Modularis Variostar. Meta-analysis of the data was done using Excel and Medcalc Soft ware. : Th e mean age of subjects was 38 ± 5.8 yrs.Th ere were 77 (57.46%) men and 57 (42.53%) wom-en subjects. Among all, 41 (30.59%) of the patients underwent DJ stenting. Average size of calculus was 1.43 ± 0.44cm. Th e calculus occupied upper-calyx in 34.32%, middle-calyx in 27.61%, lower-calyx in 14.17% and Renal pelvis in 23.88% of patients. Th e average number of shocks was 2182 ± 478 in each setting. Th e average energy expended in each setting to fragment a calculus was 62.49J. Patents with higher BMI needed signifi cantly more Energy as well as more ESWL sittings for complete clearance (P=0.040). Upper, middle calyx and Pelvis had clearance rate of 97.39% and lower calyx 78.94%. No or poor fragmentation was seen in 3 (2.23%) cases who underwent PCNL, RIRS and URS on a later date. : ESWL still remains the primary option in treatment of Solitary renal calculi less than 2 cm in size. Stone size, site, composition and BMI are important factors aff ecting outcome of ESWL. Hao Y, Xiao C, Ma L Peking University Th ird Hospital, Beijing, China Introduction and Objective:

TABREF254.text: Abdulwahab-AhmedA 1,2 , De S 2 , Gao T 2 , Noble M 2 , Monga M 2 1 Usmanu Danfodiyo University Sokoto, Nigeria; Glickman Urological & Kidney Institute, Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, USA Introduction and Objective:To evaluate the eff ect of pre-procedure intravenous (IV) Acetaminophen on sedation requirements and patient perceived pain score during and immediately aft er extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (SWL) under conscious sedation. and Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the records of patients with renal or proximal ureteral calculi who underwent SWL with conscious sedation over a one-year period. Twenty six subjects (Acetaminophen group) received intravenous Acetaminophen before SWL while 61 subjects were not given intravenous Acetaminophen (Control Group). Th e UP.350,Table 1. RIRS in Abnormal Kidney records reviewed include demographic data, stone size, stone location, pain scores (before, during and at completion of the procedure), shock rate, shock energy and dose requirements of conscious sedation agents (Midazolam and Fentanyl). Descriptive statistics was used to analyze all variables while t-test and multivariate analyses were done to compare variables between the two groups. : Eighty seven patients underwent SWL under sedation during the one-year period. Th e gender distribution was 74% male and the mean age was 49.7±11.9 years. Mean BMI is 27.3±4.4. Th ere was no signifi cant diff erence between the Acetaminophen group and Control group with regards to demograph-ic characteristics. Pre-procedure IV Acetaminophen resulted in a signifi cant reduction in the dose requirements for midazolam(1.77±0.47  vs. 3.02±1.38 mg, p=0.0001) and fentanyl (99.04±27.82 vs. 167.62±76.97 μg, p=0.0001). No signifi cant diff erence was noted in intra-operative (1.81±1.74 vs. 1.87±2.16, p=0.89) or post-operative pain (0.58±1.53 vs. 0.46±1.2, P= 0.73) between the two groups.

TABREF257.text: Introduction and Objective:Th e objective of this study was to evaluate the results of outpatient treatment of upper tract urinary stones by rigid or fl exible ureteroscopy. and Methods: A prospectively maintained database was created at the same time as the outpatient surgery department. Eighty-two patients underwent 92 ureteroscopic procedures for upper urinary tract stones from June 2013 to March 2015. : Th e majority of our patients were male with 47 men (sex ratio M / F 1.3) and middle-aged 52.9±15 years (23.4 to 82.4). A total of 45.6% of ureteroscopies performed were fl exible ureteroscopies, 29.4% rigid ureteroscopies and 25% associated rigid and fl exible ureteroscopies. Th e average stone density evaluated on preoperative scans was 964.9±286.7 HU. Th e average stone load was 10.1±5.7 mm (2-30). Th e mean operating time was 58.3±21.1 min (20-150). Th e majority of patients had a JJ stent preoperatively. A JJ stent was left in place aft er 60 procedures (65.2%).

Comparison of Clinical and Pathological Characteristics between Patients with and without Intravesical Recurrence for UTUC after Renal Transplantation (n = 37) Introduction and Objective: Extirpative treatment of Upper Urinary Tract Urothelial Carcinoma (UTUC)has long been the standard of care regardless of tumor grade. We herein stratify oncologic outcomes based on tumor grade with implications for the role of systemic chemotherapy. We present long-term oncologic outcomes of all patients treated with nephroureterectomy for UTUC over an 18 year time period. and Methods: All patients (N=114) were treated by a single surgeon with extirpative surgery for UTUC as a primary treatment. One hundred and three (90%) underwent laparoscopic nephroureterectomy via a retroperitoneal approach, with transurethral incision of the ureteric orifi ce and then open bladder-cuff excision through a Gibson incision. Th e open surgical was used in 11 (10%) cases. Data was prospectively collected and concurrent outpatient follow-up data were retrospectively reviewed. Statistical analysis was performed using Kaplan Meier methodology to calculate overall survival (OS), cancer specific survival (CSS), and metastasis free survival (MFS). : Th e mean age of patients was 71.8 (range 46-94), 67 male (59%) and mean Charlson Comorbidity Index of 5.6 (range 0-13). Mean follow-up time was 64.0 months (range 1-186) with median overall survival 107.1 months. Twenty-seven patients (23.7%) with low grade tumors, treated with nephroureterectomy, had 2-, 5-, and 10-year CSS of 100, 92, and 92%. In contrast, 87 (76.3%) with high grade tumors had a lower 2-, 5-, and 10-year CSS of 68, 58 and 32% (p<0.0003). Likewise, MFS was worse for high grade disease at 2-, 5-, and 10-years of 69, 60, and 39% compared to low grade disease of 93, 93, and 93% (p<0.005). : Tumor grade is a signifi cant predictor of OS, CSS, and MFS in patients treated with nephroureterectomy for UTUC. Extirpative therapy alone was found to result in relatively poor long-term CSS in patients with high grade disease, underscoring the need for adjuvant or neoadjuvant therapies.How Dependent Loops along Thoracostomy and Urinary Drainage Tubes Impede Drainage: An ex-vivo Model and Two Clinical Trials Garcia M 1 , Bullock T 1 , Tasian G 1 , Eisenberg M 2 , Hill A 3
